Award.AwardTitle: Vascular constraints on leaf out and flowering in plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
The timing of major events like flowering and germination mediates how plants respond to their environment, and has implications for population growth, interactions with other organisms, and large scale ecosystem processes. Relatively little is known about whether there are physiological and anatomical constraints on the timing of major events like leaf out in the spring in temperate trees. Without this knowledge, it is challenging to understand the ecological and evolutionary implications of different strategies in timing and to predict how species will respond to environmental change. The primary goal of this project is to examine the relationship between seasonal changes in the water transport system of trees and the timing of the re-distribution of resources in the early spring. This research will highlight the importance of resource mobilization in supporting leaf and flower production and examine whether vascular anatomy and physiology could explain interspecific variation in spring phenology.  A major part of the work will be completed by undergraduates, graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher, who will have the opportunity to learn valuable skills and network with scientists at multiple sites.  Research results will be used to develop laboratory curriculum on plant physiology that directly connects the vascular biology of trees to freezing tolerance. The curriculum will be used during an annual program for high school students held at the University of Minnesota Duluth.

New growth relies on resources transported in the vascular system, and therefore environmental conditions that reduce vascular function, including cold temperatures, can limit the development of new tissue. Most species in temperate environments must re-activate or repair their vascular system in the early spring before they can support young leaves and flowers. In general, there are two strategies plants use to restore vascular function: activating previously differentiated cells and/or producing new transport cells from cambial initials. It has been hypothesized that plants that rely on the production of new transport cells (at least in the xylem) cannot support early leaf out. If this is true for both the xylem and phloem, then the mechanism that species use to restore vascular function could determine how early in the growing season plants can produce leaves and flowers. To test this hypothesis, this study will characterize the relationship between plant phenology and the mechanism of vascular re-activation in deciduous, woody species. Because floral hydration does not always require both parts of the vascular system, this research will also examine the mechanism of floral hydration and consider its implications for floral freezing tolerance. This research will increase knowledge of vascular re-activation in the spring, which is a core part of plant physiology in seasonal climates, and help to understand vascular re-activation, a critical but understudied process in the vascular system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The spring is a time of rapid growth for many deciduous plant species that is supported by resources moved from stem and root tissue into the developing canopy. It is also a time when plants are going through many physiological changes including the re-activation of their vascular system (xylem and phloem), the tissues responsible for moving water, sugar, and nutrients inside the plant. To understand whether changes in the vascular system limit the timing of when new growth can occur, we examined seasonal vascular changes during leaf out and flowering in a series of studies and experiments. We found that the time of leaf out across species in multiple common gardens is tied to the anatomy and physiology of the xylem, the water conducting tissue of the vascular system. However, flowers require fewer resources than leaves and during early development (before the flowers open) may be primarily hydrated by the other part of the vascular system, the phloem. The phloem is an understudied part of the vascular system but could be critical to both leaf out and flowering because of its role supporting new growth in the spring.

Not all plants flower and leaf out at the same time and this has implications for both resource availability and investment in freezing tolerance. In our research, we discovered that plants that flower earlier in the growing season require fewer resources than plants flowering later in the spring because they invest more carbon and water in developing buds during the previous growing season. We also found that flowers produced earlier in the spring are more freezing tolerant than those flowering later in the season. However, leaves exhibited a different trend, and we found no correlation between freezing tolerance and leaf out time in native and non-native shrubs in Minnesota. Taken together, our research shows that there is coordination between seasonal changes in the vascular system, new growth, and the loss of freezing tolerance, but that there are important differences among leaves and flowers. This research has broader implications for our understanding of how plants adjust to different climatic conditions and increases our knowledge of vascular re-activation in the spring, which is critical to plant survival in seasonal climates.

This grant supported a citizen science program that was developed from the ground up with input from public focus groups. This input allowed us to design a program that addressed key concerns of our local community: (1) the impact of Lake Superior on seasons, (2) changes in climate and (3) tree species of interest including paper birch and green ash. We designed three permanent nature trails at different distances from the edge of Lake Superior that volunteers continue to monitor weekly throughout the growing season. Over the past four years, over 34 volunteers have committed to helping with project and logged over 200 trail visits. Additionally, we started an annual K-12 educator’s workshop and developed inquiry-driven activities that utilized online databases. These activities are targeted towards young adults, used in our workshops, and used annually in a large college class (reaching over 180 students).

In addition to our outreach program, this grant helped support the next generation of scientists including ten undergraduates, four master’s students, a postdoctoral associate, and a new assistant professor. Many of the undergraduates completed independent research associated with the grant; three of these students are co-authors on publications. Three undergraduates and one master’s student were co-mentored by an environmental educator as they served as the coordinator for our citizen science program.
